I've read tons of documentation & hype on JUnit, and how it is the 
de facto unit test tool for Java.  While I agree with a lot of the 
JUnit philosophy, I  have one major concern with it.  Perhaps there 
are articles out there that address this, but I can't find any of 
them.

As I look into JUnit, it seems that each class either has to do one 
of the following:

	extend TestCase 
	implement Test.  
	extend some other class that implements Test.  

As we all know, Java doesn't support multiple inheritance.  You can 
only extend TestCase or you business class, but not both.  If you 
want to use JUnit with a derived class, it seems you have to 
implement a lot of methods from the TestCase interface -- which 
isn't practical.

What are some of the ways people use JUnit to test classes that are 
derived classes?   Are there splinter projects that address this 
deficiency?  Or is JUnit a poor fit for derived classes?

Glenn Robitaille
